messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "lancezant" <lancezant@...> wrote:
> Since this is an existing system, the other major source of test cases
> is bug reports. Write a test to manifest each reported bug before
> doing anything to fix it. These will often be of the end-to-end or
> integration variety already recommended.
>
> Besides accumulating a regression suite, this has a couple of other
> benefits. First, bugs tend to occur in clusters, so you'll tend to
> accumulate the most tests for the most problematic code. Second,
> the code that is the most problematic will probably also be the
> hardest to test, encouraging refactoring. Again, focusing on bug
> hot-spots tends to focus your efforts where they're needed most.
>
> Good hunting,
> Lance

I'm starting to understand what the relationship is between designing
and testing...

Some weeks ago I read about a commercial testing tool that enables you
to write interface(GUI)-tests through JUnit tests, it sounds quite
strange (to use JUnit for end-to-end/integration testing)...

Thanks, Lance
